results.title: The Roots of tomorrow
results.creator_credit: A Peter Amavasi, Franta G. Herman, Malayan Film Unit and United Nations. Office of Public Information
results.brief_description: Emphasises the need for co-operation of Asian countries in economic development, showing work on the Asian Highway, the Mekong River Project and Regional Training Centres in India and Pakistan.

results.title: The Rooftop hopper = Halfaouine
results.creator_credit: Ferid Boughedir, Cine Tele Films, France Media and Scarabee
results.brief_description: Noura (Selim Boughedir) lives in Halfaouine, a popular quarter of the old city of Tunis. Like many adolescent boys he wants to know more about women and he increases his knowledge through his trips to the local bathhouse with his mother. The interaction between Noura, his mother, and other women in the bathhouse makes for comic moments as well as a sharp insight into relations between the sexes in the Arab community. Cast includes Mohamed Driss, Mustafa Aduenie and Rabia Ben Abdallah. Included as part of Africa 95, a nationwide season of the arts of Africa, screened throughout the United Kingdom in 1995.

results.title: The Romance of glassmaking. Part 1
results.brief_description: Glassmaking is an art that was practised by the ancient Egyptians. Made since 1680 at the White Friars Glass Works, England, the practice is still carried on by craftsmen in the works of James Powell & Sons (White Friars) at Wealdstone. Film demonstrates the art from the clay preparation through to the finished object.

results.title: The Romance of brown coal
results.creator_credit: Frank Hurley and State Electricity Commission of Victoria
results.brief_description: Illustrates how brown coal has been formed in the Latrobe Valley. Also shows the mining of brown coal and the conveyance of the coal from the open cut to the power house and briquetting plant.

results.title: The Roman world
results.brief_description: The Roman empire covered a huge area from northern England to the Middle East. This program looks at the great engineering works and buildings they created, many of which are still in use today. A vast network of roads linked the empire’s cities which were richly embellished to celebrate the Romans’ conquests. These buildings, archaeological finds, models and maps are used to illustrate many aspects of life in the Roman Empire, to demonstrate their military organisation, to review their practical achievements and to show the grandeur and prosperity brought by the Pax Romana.

results.title: The Roman wall
results.brief_description: Historical film illustrating life in Britain during the Roman occupations and dealing, in particular, with Hadrian’s Wall, its construction and use as a defence against northern tribes. Shows the extent of the Roman Empire at the time of Hadrian, the significance of the Wall in relation to the Empire; construction of the defensive wall; the Roman method of defence and attack; details of buildings in which the soldiers lived and worked; military roads providing communications along the wall and with Roman Britain; the Wall as it is today.

results.title: The Rolling rice ball: a Japanese fairytale
results.brief_description: In charming animation, the film tells the story of the Japanese woodcutter who drops his luncheon rice balls in a mouse hole, then follows them down. The delightful mice show their appreciation by presenting him with costly presents to take home to his wife. A greedy hunter learns of the mice’s treasure and seeks it for himself. However, he frightens the mice, gets the treasure and learns the folly of greed.

results.title: The Roll press: a Hugh Smith shipyard machine tool
results.brief_description: Documentary explaining the significance of the roll press introduced by Hugh Smith in the early 1900s. Talks of the technical aspects of how it’s built plus its use and significance to the shipyard.

results.title: The Roll of drums
results.brief_description: A circus performer is trained to take calculated risks, he plans, practises and perfects the stunts, for which he gets paid. Often users of heavy machinery take risks which lead to serious accidents. When danger is at hand, the victim should hear a roll of drums and take evasive action.

results.title: The Role of government
results.creator_credit: David Jackson, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description: Legislation is one of the ways by which tight control is kept on environmental matters relating to public health. Looks at the way such legislation arises, how it is drafted within a Government department and the political constraints on its implementation.
